choices.text: Inhibits the Na+/K+ATPase pump of myocardial fibers

questions.text: A 50-year-old male is given digitalis for the treatment of atrial fibrillation. Which is not correct regarding digitalis
questions.solution:
Inhibits the Na+/K+ ATPase pump:

  • Digitalis inhibits the Na+/K+ ATPase pump in myocardial fibers, leading to increased intracellular calcium ([Ca²+]), which enhances cardiac contractility.

Increases vagal tone:

  • Digitalis increases vagal tone, helping to control the ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation, contrary to option B.

Decreases ventricular filling pressure:

  • It improves left ventricular emptying and subsequently decreases ventricular filling pressures, making it beneficial in heart failure.

Increases contractility:

  • Digitalis augments myocardial contractility, enhancing cardiac output and supporting heart function.

Why Not Other Options

  • A: Digitalis effectively inhibits the Na+/K+ ATPase pump.
  • C: It reduces ventricular filling pressure due to improved emptying.
  • D: Digitalis enhances contractility, improving cardiac output.

Key Takeaways:

Digitalis is crucial in managing atrial fibrillation and heart failure by increasing contractility and vagal tone while inhibiting the Na+/K+ ATPase pump. It does not decrease vagal tone, making option B incorrect. Understanding these effects is essential for effective cardiac care.

choices.text: Located in eyes and helps in vision

questions.text: The patient who suffered from arrhythmia was given Ivabradine that is a funny current blocker. Which of the following is not correct regarding funny currents (HCN channels).
questions.solution:
Located in Heart (SA node):

  • Funny currents, or HCN channels, are indeed located in the heart, particularly in the sinoatrial (SA) node, contributing to pacemaker activity.

Helps in heart rate generation:

  • HCN channels play a vital role in generating the heart rate by allowing sodium (Na+) and potassium (K+) ions to flow, which is essential for pacemaker activity.

Opened by Cyclic AMP:

  • This is incorrect; HCN channels are primarily activated by cyclic GMP, not cyclic AMP.

Located in eyes and helps in vision:

  • HCN channels are also present in the retina and are involved in visual processes, which supports the correctness of this statement.

Why Not Other Options

  • A: HCN channels are located in the heart, particularly in the SA node.
  • B: They are essential for heart rate generation by controlling the depolarization in pacemaker cells.
  • D: HCN channels are located in the eyes and contribute to visual signaling.

Key Takeaways:

HCN channels (funny currents) are crucial for heart rate regulation and visual processes. They are located in the heart and eyes, activated by cyclic GMP, making option C incorrect. Understanding their functions enhances knowledge of cardiac electrophysiology and vision.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male came to the emergency department. Prolongation of the QT interval was observed on an electrocardiogram. Which of the following drug should be avoided by this patient?
questions.solution:
LQTS (Long QT Syndrome):

  • Prolongation of the QT interval can lead to serious complications such as irregular heartbeats, fainting, seizures, cardiac arrest, or even death.

Genetic Mutations:

  • Most cases are linked to genetic mutations in cardiac ion channels, particularly KCNQ1 or KCNH2 (voltage-gated K+ channels), accounting for ~90% of mutation-related LQTS. Other channels, like SCN5A (Na+) and CACNA1C (Ca²+), may also be involved.

Drug Avoidance:

  • Patients with LQTS should avoid medications that prolong the QT interval or that can lower serum potassium (K+) or magnesium (Mg²+) levels. Drugs like Sotalol, Amiodarone, and Quinidine are antiarrhythmics that significantly prolong the QT interval.
  • Hypothermia, class 1a and class 3 anti arrythmics can also cause long QT syndrome.

Why Not Other Options

  • A: Sotalol prolongs the QT interval and should be avoided.
  • B: Amiodarone is known to cause QT prolongation.
  • C: Quinidine also extends the QT interval and poses risks in LQTS patients.

Key Takeaways:

In patients with prolonged QT interval or LQTS, it is critical to avoid all drugs that can further prolong the QT interval, such as Sotalol, Amiodarone, and Quinidine. Understanding these drug interactions is essential for preventing life-threatening arrhythmias.

choices.text: Additional aberrant pathway present called bundle of kent

questions.text: A 52-year old male came to the hospital and was diagnosed as the case of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW). Which of the following is not correct regarding this?
questions.solution:
Short PR interval:

  • WPW is characterized by a short PR interval on the ECG, not a long one. This is due to the presence of an accessory pathway that allows for faster conduction.

Bundle of Kent:

  • The condition involves an additional aberrant pathway, known as the bundle of Kent, which connects the atria and ventricles, bypassing the normal AV node and facilitating accelerated conduction.

Accelerated AV conduction:

  • In WPW, there is indeed accelerated conduction through the accessory pathway, leading to a faster heart rate.

Paroxysmal atrial tachycardias:

  • Patients with WPW frequently experience paroxysmal atrial tachycardias due to the reentrant circuits created by the accessory pathway.

Why Not Other Options

  • B: The presence of the bundle of Kent is a hallmark of WPW.
  • C: Accelerated conduction through the accessory pathway occurs in WPW.
  • D: Paroxysmal atrial tachycardias are commonly observed in patients with WPW.

Key Takeaways:

Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome is characterized by a short PR interval and the presence of an accessory pathway (bundle of Kent), leading to accelerated AV conduction and paroxysmal atrial tachycardias. Understanding these features is crucial for proper diagnosis and management.

choices.text: Phase 0 occurs due to influx of Ca2+
Phase 1 occurs due to influx of Na+
Phase 2 occurs due to entry of Ca-+ channel via T-type Ca2-+ channels
Phase 3 occurs due to efflux of K+

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding ventricular muscle action potential shown below:
questions.solution:
Phase 0 (Depolarization):

This phase occurs due to the influx of Na+, not Ca²+. Rapid depolarization is primarily driven by sodium channels opening.

Phase 1 (Early Repolarization):

Phase 1 is characterized by efflux of K+ from the myocyte via transient potassium channels, leading to a brief drop in membrane potential.

Phase 2 (Plateau):

Phase 2 is marked by the entry of Ca²+ through L-type Ca²+ channels, not T-type channels, contributing to the plateau of the action potential.

Phase 3 (Late Repolarization):

This phase involves the efflux of K+ through delayed rectifier potassium channels, resulting in repolarization of the membrane.

Why Not Other Options

  • A: False. Phase 0 is primarily due to the influx of Na+.
  • B: False. Phase 1 is due to K+ efflux, not Na+ influx.
  • C: False. Phase 2 involves L-type Ca²+ channels, not T-type.

Key Takeaways:

Ventricular muscle action potential consists of distinct phases, with Phase 3 correctly identified as the phase associated with efflux of K+, leading to repolarization. Understanding these phases is essential for grasping cardiac electrophysiology and the mechanics of heart function.

choices.text: Phase 3, due to inactivation of voltage gated calcium channel
Phase 0, due to opening of voltage gated calcium channel
Phase 4, due to inactivation of voltage gated sodium channel
Phase 0, due to opening of voltage gated sodium channel

questions.text: Identify the depolarization phase in the below diagram and how are they initiated?
questions.solution:
• Phase 0 (Depolarization):
    • Characterized by a rapid influx of calcium ions (Ca²+) into the myocardial cells.
    • Initiated by the opening of voltage-gated calcium channels, primarily L-type calcium channels.
    • This influx of Ca²+ leads to a significant rise in the membrane potential, causing depolarization.
    • Important for the contraction of cardiac muscle fibers, facilitating effective heartbeats.
  • Phase 3 (Repolarization):
    • Marked by the efflux of K+ ions from the cell.
    • Potassium channels, particularly delayed rectifier channels, open during this phase, allowing K+ to exit.
    • This repolarization restores the membrane potential toward its resting state after depolarization.
  • Phase 4 (Prepotential):
    • Involves a gradual influx of Ca²+ through transient calcium channels(Ttype)
    • Features a slow influx of Na+ due to the funny current (HCN channels), which is crucial for the pacemaker activity in nodal tissues.
    • Decreased potassium efflux contributes to the gradual depolarization that leads back into Phase 0.

Why Not Other Options

  • A: Phase 3 involves K+ efflux, not the inactivation of calcium channels.
  • C: Phase 4 is not solely related to sodium channel inactivation; it involves multiple ion movements.
  • D: While Phase 0 does involve sodium influx, it is more directly characterized by calcium channel activity, making option B more precise.

Key Takeaways:

Phase 0 represents depolarization, initiated by the opening of voltage-gated calcium channels, leading to a rapid influx of Ca²+. This process is vital for cardiac muscle contraction. Understanding these phases and their dynamics enhances insight into cardiac electrophysiology and the mechanisms governing heart function.

choices.text: PR Interval - Atrial depolarization and AV conduction time
QT interval - Ventricular depolarization and ventricular repolarization
ST interval - Plateau portion of ventricular action potential + Ventricular repolarization

questions.text: Identify the incorrect match among the following:
questions.solution:
• PR Interval:
    • Represents atrial depolarization and the time taken for conduction through the AV node.
    • Normal duration is 12 to 0.20 seconds.
  • QT Interval:
    • Encompasses both ventricular depolarization and repolarization.
    • Normal duration can be up to 43 seconds.
  • QRS Complex:
    • This complex reflects ventricular depolarization, not repolarization.
    • Normal duration is typically up to 10 seconds.
  • ST Interval:
    • Represents the plateau phase of the ventricular action potential and includes the beginning of ventricular repolarization.
    • Duration is around 32 seconds.

Why Not Other Options

  • A: The PR interval correctly describes atrial depolarization and AV conduction time.
  • B: The QT interval accurately encompasses ventricular depolarization and repolarization.
  • D: The ST interval indeed corresponds to the plateau phase of the action potential and early repolarization.

Key Takeaways:

The incorrect match is that the QRS complex represents ventricular depolarization, not repolarization. Understanding these definitions is crucial for interpreting ECG findings and recognizing cardiac electrical activity accurately.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male was brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state. He is having history of coronary artery disease. He was having symptoms of palpitations and dizziness for the past few days. His ECG is showing disordered electrical ventricular activation with no identifiable QRS complexes, no identifiable P-waves and no PR interval. What will be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Ventricular Fibrillation (VF):
    • Characterized by disordered electrical activation of the ventricles.
    • No identifiable QRS complexes are present, indicating chaotic electrical activity.
    • There are no identifiable P-waves and no PR interval, demonstrating a complete lack of organized electrical conduction.
  • Ventricular Tachycardia (VT):
    • Typically features a wide QRS complex with abnormal morphology.
    • There is usually absence of P waves, but the rate is typically greater than 100/min.
  • Polymorphic VT and Torsades de Pointes:
    • These conditions also show a wide QRS complex but differ in rhythm and morphology.
    • Torsades de Pointes specifically involves a pattern of changing morphology with a prolonged QT interval.

Why Not Other Options

  • A: Polymorphic VT shows varying QRS morphology and is organized enough to discern a pattern, which is not seen in this case.
  • C: Monomorphic VT would have identifiable wide QRS complexes and an organized rhythm.
  • D: Torsades de Pointes has a characteristic changing QRS morphology and is usually related to prolonged QT interval.

Key Takeaways:

The most probable diagnosis is ventricular fibrillation, characterized by disordered electrical activity with no identifiable QRS complexes or P-waves. Recognizing these ECG features is crucial for timely intervention in emergency cardiac care.

questions.text: A 53-year old woman was brought to the hospital after she became unconscious in the marriage party. Her ECG shows the following. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• First Degree Heart Block:
    • Defined by a prolonged PR interval (greater than 0.20 seconds).
    • Every P wave is followed by a QRS complex.
  • Mobitz Type I Heart Block (Wenckebach Phenomenon):
    • The PR interval progressively lengthens until one P wave is not followed by a QRS complex.
    • Exhibits a pattern of dropped beats.
  • Mobitz Type II Heart Block:
    • The PR interval remains constant throughout the cycles.
    • There are intermittent dropped QRS complexes despite consistent PR intervals.
  • Complete Heart Block (Third Degree):
    • There is no relationship between P waves and QRS complexes; atrial and ventricular contractions are independent.

Why Not Other Options

  • A: First degree heart block is characterized by a constant prolonged PR interval without dropped beats.
  • B: Mobitz Type I involves a lengthening PR interval until a beat is dropped, which is not indicated here.
  • D: Complete heart block would show no correlation between P waves and QRS complexes, rather than a constant PR interval.

Key Takeaways:

The most probable diagnosis is Mobitz type II heart block, marked by a constant PR interval with occasional dropped QRS complexes. Recognizing the differences between heart block types is essential for timely management and intervention in cardiac emergencies.

choices.text: Anterior wall MI - I, aVL, V1-V4
Inferior wall MI - II, III, aVF
Posterior wall MI - I, aVL, V1-V6
Septal wall MI - I, aVL, V1-V2

questions.text: A 62-year-old man was brought to the emergency department with severe, sudden-onset chest pain radiating to the left arm. ECG showed ST segment elevation in precordial leads. He is diagnosed as the case of Myocardial Infarction. Which one of the following is incorrect localization of area of myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
• Anterior Wall Myocardial Infarction:
    • Identified by ST elevation in leads I, aVL, V1-V4.
    • Involves the left anterior descending artery.
  • Inferior Wall Myocardial Infarction:
    • Associated with ST elevation in leads II, III, aVF.
    • Typically involves the right coronary artery.
  • Posterior Wall Myocardial Infarction:
    • Correct localization should involve reciprocal ST depressions in leads V1 to V3 and not ST elevations in I, aVL, V1-V6.
    • Often presents with dominant R waves in V2 and V3.
  • Septal Wall Myocardial Infarction:
    • Recognized by ST elevation in leads I, aVL, V1-V2.
    • Typically involves the septal branches of the left anterior descending artery.

Why Not Other Options

  • A: Anterior wall MI is accurately localized to leads I, aVL, V1-V4.
  • B: Inferior wall MI is correctly associated with leads II, III, aVF.
  • D: Septal wall MI corresponds to leads I, aVL, V1-V2.

Key Takeaways:

The incorrect localization is for posterior wall MI, which does not show ST elevations in leads I, aVL, V1-V6 but instead exhibits reciprocal ST depressions in leads V1 to V3. Accurate ECG interpretation is crucial for effective diagnosis and treatment of myocardial infarctions.

choices.text: Indicates spread of the polarizing current

questions.text: Point "a" indicates which of the following
questions.solution:
Option C: J Point: Represents the moment when all parts of the ventricles have fully depolarized, including both damaged and normal areas.

  • Voltage at J Point: No current flows, so the electrocardiogram (ECG) potential is at zero voltage.
  • Clinical Relevance: The relative elevation or depression of the TP segment compared to the isoelectric J point aids in diagnosing myocardial infarction.

Why not other options:

Option A: Indicates Spread of Depolarizing Current: This is incorrect as the J point signifies the end of depolarization, not its spread.

Option B: Indicates Spread of the Polarizing Current: This is also incorrect since the J point occurs after depolarization is complete, meaning no current is spreading.

Option D: Current of Injury: This refers to abnormal currents typically seen in conditions like myocardial infarction and is not represented by the J point, which indicates the end of depolarization.

Key takeaways:

The J point indicates complete depolarization of the ventricles, as all parts are depolarized, resulting in zero voltage and no current flow at this instant.

questions.text: The ECG recording of a patient showed decreased PR interval, prolonged QRS, normal PJ interval. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Option A: Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) Syndrome: Characterized by:

  • Decreased PR Interval: Indicates rapid conduction through the accessory pathway (Bundle of Kent).
  • Prolonged QRS Complex: Due to fusion of normal and abnormal conduction pathways.

Differential Diagnosis:

Lown-Ganong-Levine (LGL) Syndrome: It is a pre excitation syndrome. They have episodes of abnormal heart racing with short PR interval and normal QRS interval.

Stokes-Adams Syndrome: Refers to fainting due to SA node failure, not related to these ECG changes.

Myocardial Infarction (MI): Typically presents with ST elevation or depression, not these specific changes.

Why not other options:

Option B: Lown-Ganong-Levine Syndrome: This condition typically presents with a normal QRS duration and a short PR interval, but does not cause a prolonged QRS complex.

Option C: Stokes Adams Syndrome: This syndrome involves episodes of syncope due to transient loss of cardiac output, not specifically associated with the ECG changes described.

Option D: MI (Myocardial Infarction): MI would show ST segment changes (elevation or depression) and does not specifically correlate with decreased PR interval and prolonged QRS without other characteristic findings.

Key takeaways:

The most likely diagnosis for a patient with a decreased PR interval, prolonged QRS, and normal PJ interval is Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, characterized by an accessory conduction pathway that leads to these ECG changes.

questions.text: 49-year-old male developed chest pain, nausea and uneasiness. On investigation, ECG shows ST segment elevation. The probable diagnosis is Myocardial infarction. The best cardiac marker marker is:
questions.solution:
Option C: Troponin I is the best cardiac marker for diagnosing myocardial infarction.

  • Timing: Troponin I rises in 2-4 hours after injury and remains elevated for 7-10 days.
  • Specificity: It is highly specific for cardiac injury.
  • Other Markers:
    • LDH: Normally, LDH2 > LDH1, but in myocardial infarction, this reverses (LDH Flip).
    • CK-MB: Good for detecting re-infarction, rising in 2-4 hours and falling in 2-3 days.
    • Myoglobin: One of the earliest markers to rise (within 1 hour) but lacks specificity, falling within 24 hours.

Why Not Others:

Option A: LDH: Not specific for myocardial infarction and has a delayed rise compared to troponin.

Option B: CK-MB: Good for re-infarction but less sensitive and specific than troponin I for initial diagnosis.

Option D: Myoglobin: Rises early but lacks specificity for myocardial infarction, as it can be elevated in other conditions.

Key takeaways:

The best cardiac marker for diagnosing myocardial infarction is Troponin I, as it rises within 2-4 hours and remains elevated for 7-10 days.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has a resting heart rate of 70-beats/min. Her pressure-volume diagram of the left ventricle is given below. What is her cardiac output (in ml/min)?
questions.solution:
Cardiac output (CO) is calculated using the formula: CO=SV×HR

  • Where SV (stroke volume) is the difference between end-diastolic volume (EDV) and end-systolic volume (ESV).
  • In this case:
    • EDV = 120 ml
    • ESV = 50 ml
    • SV = EDV - ESV = 120 ml - 50 ml = 70 ml
  • Heart Rate (HR) = 70 beats/min
  • Substituting values into the CO formula: CO=70 ml×70 beats/min=4900 ml/min.

Why not other options:

  • 2000 ml/min:
    • Incorrect. This value does not correspond to the calculated stroke volume and heart rate; it significantly underestimates the cardiac output based on the provided parameters.
  • 3000 ml/min:
    • Incorrect. This option also does not match the expected cardiac output calculation using the given stroke volume and heart rate.
  • 7000 ml/min:
    • Incorrect. This value overestimates the cardiac output, as it implies a much higher stroke volume or heart rate than what is provided.

Key Takeaways:

  • The cardiac output calculation utilizes stroke volume and heart rate.
  • Accurate measurements from the pressure-volume diagram are critical for determining cardiac performance.
  • In this scenario, the calculated cardiac output is 4900 ml/min, consistent with the physiological parameters of the patient.

choices.text: Decreased cardiac output due to decreased preload
Increased cardiac output due to decreased systemic vascular resistance
Decreased cardiac output due to cardiac depression
Increased cardiac output due to increased afterload

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with severe burns over 40% of the total body surface area (TBSA) is admitted to the burn unit. On the third day of admission, the patient develops signs of septic shock, including hypotension, tachycardia, and a warm periphery. Despite aggressive fluid resuscitation, the patient remains hypotensive and oliguric. Which of the following is most likely regarding the patient's cardiac output at this stage?
questions.solution:
• In septic shock, especially in patients with extensive burns:
    • Cardiac output (CO) often increases due to compensatory mechanisms.
    • Widespread vasodilation and systemic inflammation lead to decreased systemic vascular resistance (SVR). It causes persistent hypotension and oliguria.
    • The heart compensates for this vasodilation by increasing its output to maintain tissue perfusion.
  • Early (Hyperdynamic Phase):
    • CO typically rises to counteract the effects of low SVR and maintain perfusion to vital organs despite hypotension.

Why not other options:

  • Decreased cardiac output due to decreased preload:
    • Incorrect. While hypotension may suggest reduced preload, in septic shock, the body often increases CO to compensate, resulting in an overall increase in output despite fluid status.
  • Decreased cardiac output due to cardiac depression:
    • Incorrect. Although cardiac function may be affected in severe cases, the hyperdynamic response typically prevails in the early stages of septic shock, leading to increased CO rather than decreased.
  • Increased cardiac output due to increased afterload:
    • Incorrect. In septic shock, afterload generally decreases due to vasodilation; therefore, any increase in CO is not due to increased afterload.

Key Takeaways:

  • In septic shock, the body often responds with increased cardiac output despite hypotension due to decreased systemic vascular resistance.
  • Understanding these hemodynamic changes is critical in managing fluid resuscitation and ensuring adequate organ perfusion in burn patients experiencing septic shock.

questions.text: Look at the following graph representing the relationship between venous return and cardiac output. Based on this graph, which physiological law explains the increase in cardiac output with an increase in venous return?
questions.solution:
• The Frank-Starling law of the heart states that:
    • Stroke volume (SV) and consequently cardiac output (CO) increase as the volume of blood returning to the heart (venous return)
    • Greater venous return stretches the heart muscle fibers, resulting in a stronger contraction due to the optimal overlap of actin and myosin filaments in cardiac muscle cells.
    • This mechanism ensures that the heart can adjust its output to match the volume of blood returning, maintaining effective circulation under normal physiological conditions.

Why not other options:

  • A. Boyle's law:
    • Incorrect. This law pertains to the relationship between pressure and volume of gases, not directly related to cardiac output and venous return. Boyle's law states that the volume of a gas and pressure are inversely proportional at a given temperature
  • C. Fick's principle:
    • Incorrect. This principle is related to gas exchange and oxygen consumption, not specifically to cardiac output or venous return.
  • D. Laplace's law:
    • Incorrect. This law describes the relationship between pressure, wall tension, and radius in cylindrical structures, primarily applied in cardiovascular mechanics, but it does not directly explain the relationship between venous return and cardiac output.

Key Takeaways:

  • The Frank-Starling law effectively illustrates how an increase in venous return leads to an increase in cardiac output due to enhanced cardiac muscle fiber stretch and contraction strength.
  • This physiological mechanism is crucial for adapting to varying levels of blood return, ensuring effective cardiovascular function.

choices.text: Can be used to treat atrial fibrillations

questions.text: Which of these is not driven by Digitalis?
questions.solution:
Improves Cardiac Output:

  • Augments Contractility: Increases intracellular calcium (Ca²+) concentration, enhancing the strength of heart contractions.
  • Increased Left Ventricular Emptying: Facilitates more effective pumping of blood, leading to improved cardiac output.
  • Decreases Ventricular Filling Pressures: Reduces the pressure in the ventricles, allowing for better heart function.

AV Nodal Conduction Delay:

  • Reduces Impulses in Atrial Fibrillation: In atrial fibrillation, digitalis decreases the number of impulses transmitted through the AV node, helping to control heart rate.

B: Augments contractility - Digitalis increases calcium concentration in cardiac cells, enhancing contractility.

C: Can be used to treat atrial fibrillations - Digitalis is effective in controlling ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation by decreasing AV nodal conduction.

D: Decreases AV nodal conduction velocity - Digitalis causes a delay in conduction through the AV node, which is a key mechanism in its action during atrial fibrillation.

Key takeaways:

Digitalis enhances cardiac output by increasing contractility is used to treat atrial fibrillation and decreases AV nodal conduction velocity.

questions.text:
Choose whether sentences are T-True or F-false
1. Ventricular filling is 70% passive filling
2. Ventricular filling is fast in phase of diastasis
3. Ventricular filling is reduced by 20% in atrial fibrillation
questions.solution:
Mechanics of Filling:

  • Passive Filling: 70% of ventricular filling occurs passively during diastole.
  • Active Filling: 30% of filling occurs actively during atrial systole.

Diastasis Phase:

  • Slow Filling: Ventricular filling is slow during the diastasis phase, which is the period between rapid filling and atrial contraction.

Atrial Fibrillation Impact:

  • Reduction in Filling: Ventricular filling is reduced by 20% in cases of atrial fibrillation due to the loss of effective atrial contraction.

D: TFT is correct for above three statements. It is correct answer.

A, B and C are incorrect

Key takeaways:

Ventricular filling is 70% passive, slow during diastasis, and reduced by about 20% in atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: Which of the following would cause a decrease in cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Option c: Acute Venous Dilation:

  • Cause: Sudden inactivity of the sympathetic nervous system.
  • Effect: Causes veins to dilate, decreasing filling pressure in the vascular system. Blood pools in peripheral vessels, leading to decreased venous return and reduced cardiac output.

Option A: Beriberi (Vitamin B1 Deficiency):

  • Mechanism: Impairs tissue nutrient utilization, leading to peripheral vasodilation.
  • Effect: Decreased peripheral resistance results in increased cardiac output, which can be up to twice the normal value.

Option B: Arteriovenous (AV) Fistula:

  • Definition: An abnormal connection between a major artery and a major vein.
  • Effect: Blood flows directly from artery to vein, reducing total peripheral resistance and increasing venous return, which enhances cardiac output.

Option D: Anemia:

  • Cause: Decreased red blood cell concentration leads to lower blood viscosity.
  • Effect: Diminished oxygen delivery causes local vasodilation, reducing peripheral resistance and significantly increasing cardiac output.

Option A, B and D produces the hyperdynamic circulation leading to increased cardiac output.

Key takeaways:

Acute venous dilation, beriberi, AV fistula, and anemia reduce peripheral resistance, enhancing cardiac output through mechanisms like vasodilation and altered blood flow.

questions.text: A female patient of age 25 presented with complaints of fatigue, weight loss, abdomen and joint pain. On examination, patient found with arrhythmia, excessive pigmentation of skin along with diabetes, cirrhosis of liver and atrophy of gonads. What is your probable diagnosis for this condition?
questions.solution:
Iron Excess (Hemochromatosis)

Key Features:

  • Symptoms:
    • Fatigue, weight loss
    • Abdominal and joint pain
    • Arrhythmia and excessive skin pigmentation
    • Diabetes, cirrhosis of liver and gonadal atrophy

Mechanism:

  • Iron Overload: Occurs when iron absorption exceeds excretion due to:
    • Excessive iron intake
    • Congenital failure of mucosal feedback
    • Increased erythrocyte destruction

Consequences:

  • Hemosiderin Accumulation: Leads to tissue damage, resulting in:
    • Skin pigmentation
    • Pancreatic damage causing diabetes
    • Liver cirrhosis
    • Atrophy of glands

Why not other options:

  • B] Iron Deficiency: Presents with fatigue and pallor but not excessive pigmentation, diabetes, or cirrhosis, which are indicative of iron overload.
  • C] Vitamin B12 Deficiency: Typically causes anemia, neurological symptoms, and fatigue, but not the specific signs of diabetes and cirrhosis seen here.
  • D] Potassium Deficiency: Mainly leads to muscle weakness, cramps, and arrhythmias but does not explain the other systemic issues like pigmentation, liver cirrhosis, and diabetes.

Key takeaways: patient with fatigue, weight loss, and skin pigmentation likely has iron overload (hemochromatosis), indicated by diabetes, liver cirrhosis, and gonadal atrophy.

Key takeaways:

Acute venous dilation, beriberi, AV fistula, and anemia reduce peripheral resistance, enhancing cardiac output through mechanisms like vasodilation and altered blood flow.
